title: Middleton v. Connery Properties
text:
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"
   "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">



<!-- meta anti cache-->
 



<!--
body{
font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->



THIS OPINION HAS
  NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 268(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Tommy H. Middleton, Appellant,
				v.
				Connery Properties, Inc., Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Charleston County
Mikell R. Scarborough, Master-in-Equity
Memorandum
Opinion No. 2009-MO-036
Heard June 11, 2009 â€“ Filed July 13, 2009Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				BenjaminÂ 
  Goldberg, of Charleston, for Appellant.
				KerryÂ 
  Koon, of Charleston, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â  This
  is a direct appeal from an unsuccessful challenge to a real property delinquent
  tax sale held in Charleston County.Â  We have carefully reviewed the record, and
  we conclude that the Master-in-Equity correctly found that Charleston County complied with section 12-51-40 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2008).Â  Even
  accepting Appellantâ€™s non-compliance argument, we find no material violation of
  section 12-51-40 which resulted in any prejudice to Appellant or the owner of
  the property at the time of the delinquency, National Tax Assistance
  Corporation.Â  See Snelgrove v. Lanham, 298 S.C. 302, 304, 379 S.E.2d
  904, 905 (1989) (recognizing that in order to set aside a tax sale the county
  must commit a â€œmaterial violationâ€ of the tax sale statute).Â  We concur in the
  analysis and conclusions set forth in the order of Judge Scarborough.Â  We
  affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR.
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

title: Miller v. Unity Group
text:
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"
   "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">



<!-- meta anti cache-->
 



<!--
body{
font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->



THIS OPINION HAS
  NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 268(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Regina Miller, Plaintiff,
				v.
				The Unity Group,
      Inc., Modern Business Associates, Continental Casualty Insurance Company, and
      SCUEF, Defendants,
				of whom The
      Unity Group, Inc. Modern Business Associates is Respondent,
				and Continental
      Casualty Insurance Company is, Petitioner.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS

Appeal From Horry County
James E. Lockemy, Circuit Court Judge
Memorandum Opinion No.Â  2009-MO-037
Heard June 9, 2009 â€“ Filed July 13, 2009Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Kirsten
  L. Barr, of Trask and Howell, of Mt. Pleasant, for Petitioner.
				Natale
  Fata, of Surfside Beach, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:  We granted a writ of certiorari to review the court 
of appeals unpublished opinion in this case.  We reverse.
On the basis of a finding that The Unity Group was an â€œadditional
  insuredâ€ under Modern Business Associatesâ€™ workersâ€™ compensation insurance
  policy with Continental Casualty Insurance Company, the court of appeals
  affirmed the circuit court.Â  The circuit court had determined Continental
  Insurance had a conflict in its representation of Unity Group.Â  As a result,
  the circuit court ordered Continental Insurance to â€œappoint separate counsel to
  defend the Unity Group.â€Â  The finding of a conflict was in error.
We need not reach the question of whether Unity Group is an
  additional insured under Modern Business Associatesâ€™ policy with Continental Casualty as a result of Unity Groupâ€™s status as an alternate
  employer.Â  We decline to do so because even assuming Unity Group is an additional
  insured, its status as an insured is unquestionably restricted to Regina
  Millerâ€™s July 2002 claim in the underlying workersâ€™ compensation case; Millerâ€™s
  separate March 2002 claim occurred outside of the policy period. Â R. A. Earnhardt Textile Mach. Div., Inc. v. S.C. Ins.
    Co., 277 S.C. 88, 90, 282 S.E.2d 856,
  857 (1981) (â€œIf the alleged facts in the complaint fail to bring
  the case within the policy coverage, the insurer is free of the obligation to
  defend.â€).
The circuit court erred in finding a conflict between Continental
  Insuranceâ€™s counselâ€™s representation of Unity Group and Unity Groupâ€™s interest
  as an alleged insured.Â  We hold there was no conflict of interest as
  Continental owed no duty to defend Unity Group in Millerâ€™s March 2002 claim.
REVERSED.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

title: Raysor v. State

THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECENDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT
  IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 268(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Stacy Raysor, Respondent,
        v.
        State of South Carolina, Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Richland County
Â John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge

Memorandum Opinion No.Â  2009-MO-038
  Submitted June 24, 2009 â€“ Filed July 13,
2009Â  

DISMISSED AS IMPROVIDENTLY GRANTED


  
    
      
        Attorney
          General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
          Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Brian
          T. Petrano, all of Columbia, for Petitioner.
        JoshuaÂ 
          Kendrick, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM: The
  Court of Appeals granted certiorari to review the post-conviction relief
  courtâ€™s grant of relief to respondent Stacy Raysor.Â 
  Pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR, this Court certified the case for review.Â  We
  now dismiss the writ as improvidently granted.[1]
DISMISSED AS IMPROVIDENTLY GRANTED.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1] We note that respondent was granted summary judgment,
  and the matter was remanded to the Richland County Court of General Sessions
  for resentencing.Â  We clarify that the resentencing shall take place before a
  judge different from the original judge who presided over respondentâ€™s guilty
  plea.

title: Duncan v. Little
text:
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"
   "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">



<!-- meta anti cache-->
 



<!--
body{
font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->



THIS OPINION HAS
  NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 268(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Ann G. Duncan,
          as Personal Representative of the Estate of Frankie Galloway, deceased, and
          Cleo Galloway, Respondents,
        v.
        Samuel D.
          Little, personally and as Personal Representative of the Estate of Joseph A.
          Galloway, a/k/a Avery Galloway, deceased; Betty Joy L. Iannazzone, personally
          and as Personal Representative of the estate of Joseph A. Galloway,
          deceased;  the Estate of Joseph A. Galloway, a/k/a Avery Galloway, deceased;
          and SunTrust Banks, Inc., formerly Central Carolina Bank, a/k/a CCB,
          Defendants,
        Of whom Samuel D. Little, personally and as Personal
          Representative of the Estate of Joseph A. Galloway, a/k/a Avery Galloway,
          deceased, is Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Pickens County
Â Charles B. Simmons, Jr., Special Referee

Memorandum Opinion No. 2009-MO-040
Heard April 7, 2009 â€“ Filed July 20, 2009

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Dallas Ball, of Pickens and Sally Calhoun, of Beaufort, for
          Appellant.
        Larry
          Brandt, of Walhalla, for Respondents.
      
    
  


PER
  CURIAM:Â  This is an appeal from a Special Refereeâ€™s finding of a
  constructive trust.Â  Appellant Samuel D. Little (â€œLittleâ€) appeals.Â  We affirm.
The
  facts, as we borrow heavily from Littleâ€™s brief, are as follows.Â  In early June 2003, Frankey Galloway, aging and
  paraplegic, was admitted into a nursing home while being treated for an
  illness.Â  Frankey, who had stored away his life savings in cash at various
  locations in his home, feared its safety in his absence and asked his brother
  Cleo to collect the money and store it in a safe deposit box.Â  Cleo went to
  Frankeyâ€™s house, found the cash in the locations Frankey described, and took it
  home where he counted it in the presence of his wife and daughter.Â  Cleo
  tallied two hundred fifty-three thousand, eight hundred and forty-three dollars
  ($253,843.00), and reported this sum to Frankey, who confirmed that figure
  matched his expectation of the value of the stored cash.Â  Cleo placed the cash
  in a safe deposit box at a Wachovia Bank branch in Pickens, South Carolina.Â  Shortly
  thereafter, the money was removed and placed in two safe deposit boxes at
  Central Carolina Bank (â€œCCB,â€ now known as Sun Trust Bank).Â  
In August 2004,
  Frankey was released from the nursing home and Cleo and another brother, Avery,
  gave him four keys to the safe deposit boxes.Â  Cleo and Avery were listed on the
  lease agreement as co-lessees.
On
  November 24, 2004, Avery passed away.Â  In accordance with Averyâ€™s will, his
  stepson Little and stepdaughter Betty Joy Innazzone (â€œJoyâ€) were appointed
  personal representatives of his estate.[1]Â 
  Within a week of Averyâ€™s passing, Sammy and Joy went to CCB to ask if Avery had
  any accounts at the bank.Â  On December 4, 2004, the boxes were drilled open in
  the presence of Sammy and Joy.Â  Sammy and Joy left the bank with the cash from
  both boxes, in the amount of two hundred and twenty nine thousand, seven
  hundred and ninety-six dollars ($229,796.00).
The
  primary issue on appeal is whether the Special Referee erred in finding a
  constructive trust because he failed to exclude certain testimony pursuant to the
  Dead Manâ€™s Statute, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 19-11-20
  (2008).Â  We have reviewed the
  record on appeal, and find overwhelming evidence to support the Special
  Refereeâ€™s finding that a constructive trust was established for the benefit of
  Frankey Galloway.Â  We therefore affirm the decision of the Special Referee.Â  
AFFIRMED.
 WALLER,
  ACTING CHIEF JUSTICE, PLEICONES, BEATTY, KITTREDGE, JJ., and Acting Justice
  James E. Moore, concur.


[1] Joy is now deceased and not a party to the present appeal.Â

title: Austin v. Town of Hilton Head Island

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"

<!-- meta anti cache-->
 



<!--
body{
font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->



THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 268(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Carolyn Songer Austin, Petitioner,
				v.
				Town of Hilton
      Head Island, South Carolina, W.J. Enterprises, Inc., H.D.S. Builders, LLC,
      Barb Loebig, and National Bank of Commerce, Defendants,
				W.J.
      Enterprises, Inc., H.D.S. Builders, LLC, Barb Loebig and National Bank of
      Commerce are the Respondents.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS
Appeal from Beaufort County
Â Thomas Kemmerlin, Special Circuit Court
  Judge
Memorandum Opinion No. 2009-MO-042
Heard May 14, 2009 â€“ Filed July 27, 2009Â Â  
DISMISSED AS IMPROVIDENTLY GRANTED


	
		
			
				M.
  Adam Gess, of McDaniel & Gess, of Beaufort, Mark Weston Hardee, of Hardee
  Law Firm, of Columbia, and Robert E. Austin, Jr., of Leesburg, Florida, for
  Petitioner.
				Drew
  A. Laughlin, of Laughlin & Bowen, of Hilton Head Island and Stephen Spitz,
  of Charleston, for Respondents
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  We granted a writ of certiorari to review
  the Court of Appeals decision in Carolyn Songer Austin v. Town of Hilton
    Head Island, Op. No. 2007-UP-172 (S.C. Ct. App., filed April 17, 2007).Â  On
  certiorari, we were presented with alleged violations of restrictive covenants
  in (1) reducing a lot in size such that it has a frontage of less than 60 feet
  in length, without proper written consent and (2) building a structure closer
  than 10 feet to an adjacent street line.Â  After careful consideration, we now
  dismiss certiorari as improvidently granted.
DISMISSED.
TOAL, C.J.,
  WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.
